DOC.HEAD: Iran Denies Oil Sold To Israel
DOC.TEXT: Iran's Foreign Ministry on Wednesday denied a U.S. report that Israel bought oil from Tehran in a bid to free three military men believed held by pro-Iranian militants in Lebanon, Iranian TV reported. The broadcast, monitored in Cyprus, quoted a Foreign Ministry statement as saying that ``not even one barrel of oil'' had been sold to Israel, one of revolutionary Iran's main regional foes. ``According to irrevocable, declared principles of the Islamic Republic, the Oil Ministry has imposed a ban on the sale of oil and oil-related products to Israel and the racist South African regime,'' the statement said. Tehran has vowed never to establish relations with Israel and South Africa. The statement added that no oil has been sold to those countries since Iran's 1979 Islamic revolution, which toppled Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi. The U.S. State Department on Tuesday confirmed an NBC-TV report Monday that Israel bought 2 million barrels of oil worth $36 million from Iran in November to help free the three Israelis held in Lebanon. Israeli representatives also have discussed the possibility of selling Iran spare parts for its U.S.-made military hardware, NBC said, citing unidentified sources in U.S. and Israeli intelligence. In addition to winning Iran's help in releasing the Israelis, the oil purchases and the potential spare parts deal were intended to bolster Iran's position against Iraq, their common enemy, NBC said. Spokesmen for Israel's Energy, Foreign and Defense ministries refused to comment on the report. NBC reported that the U.S. government had backed the oil deal in hopes that it could help the release of eight American hostages in Lebanon. They are among 18 Westerners held in Lebanon by extremist groups. Most are captives of Iranian-backed Shiite factions. Iran's leaders are avowedly anti-Israeli, but the Iranian economy, battered by 10 years of poor management and 8 years of war against Iraq, badly needs foreign exchange for post-war reconstruction. President Hashemi Rafsanjani was closely involved in clandestine arms-for-hostages dealings with the United States and Israel in 1985-86. Three American hostages held in Lebanon were freed in exchange for deliveries of U.S.-made anti-aircraft and anti-tank missile parts. Rafsanjani, leader of Tehran's so-calle pragmatists, is seeking to rebuild Iran's links with the West to end 10 years of isolation and seek badly needed investment. He generally is considered to be in favor of freeing the hostages held in Lebanon, but has limited room to maneuver because of opposition by hard-liners led by former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, who has close ties with the Lebanese militants.
